Topic.Title: Why the x86 vendors are missing big desktop PC opportunities in race for mobile. Part 1

Message.Msg: 'One of the biggest textbook mistakes IBM ever made was agreeing with Sun that the mainframe was dead - allegedly to be replaced by PCs and client server computing.' This assertion only exists in the mind of the author, IBM have a 45nm 5.2 GHz quad-core mainframe chip so they never stopped developing and supporting it. Sparc/Solaris has outlasted Sun as Ellison is still very keen on it so they never stopped believing in their enterprise server version either.

Message.Title: Tom'sHardware: Hands on with NVIDIA Project Shield (very positive review and informative!)
Message.Msg: Our first stop at this year's CES was Nvidia's suite in the Palms, where company representatives showed off pre-production versions of its Shield handheld. Chris Angelini weighs in with some of the specifics, plus his impressions of Nvidia's effort. We were still in Southern California when Nvidia introduced its Project Shield. But that didn't stop Don and I from following the webcast and posting our initial thoughts online in CES 2013: Nvidia Announces Project Shield And Tegra 4. The next day, the Tom’s Hardware team landed in Las Vegas, ready for the show (more specifically, everyone else landed; I drove). My first stop was Nvidia, where I got to go hands-on with a pre-production version of the Shield. The company was emphatic that what you saw during Jen-Hsun’s introduction was an early version of the hardware; it isn’t expected to ship until the second quarter of this year, and will be among the first devices with Tegra 4 inside. Gaming On Android I’ll preface this with what I told Nvidia: I don’t spend a lot of time gaming on mobile devices. I think I might have a free version of Angry Birds installed on my iPhone, and it’d take something really compelling to make me want to buy a game on one of my Windows 8 or Android tablets. With that said, the build of Hawken the company had running on its Shield looked surprisingly detailed. I figured I could get pretty good at the game using the handheld’s joysticks. It’s a shame that the UDK-based title's free-to-play model is already being derided for goading you into buying upgrades with real-world currency just to stay competitive. We’ll have to see if Meteor’s model carries over from Windows into Android. Nvidia is quick to point out a few other upcoming titles with planned optimizations for Tegra 4: Blood Sword: Sword of Ruin, Real Boxing, and Dead Trigger 2. My only beef with the optimizations developers are making (first mentioned in Nvidia's Tegra 3 Optimizations: THD Android Games, Tested), is that they’re restricted under Android via device detection. But when you play a cross-platform title under iOS or Windows, that detection doesn’t always happen. In some games, you see the same effects on SoCs from Apple, Qualcomm, and Intel. Will the first wave of Tegra 4-optimized titles run smoothly on A6/A6X, Snapdragon S4, and Atom Z2760? Or will Tegra 4’s more powerful graphics subsystem enable games that can only be enjoyed at their highest settings on Nvidia’s Shield? More so now than on the prior generation of hardware, Shield stands to enjoy a notable advantage in Android-based games right out of the gate. The Wizard Behind The Curtain Much of what Shield can do beyond gaming natively in Android is owed to Nvidia’s other technologies. For example, the device is able to access your library of PC games through Valve’s Steam platform and present them neatly on-screen. Actually firing them up and playing them, however, requires a desktop PC with at least a GeForce GTX 650 or a notebook with a GeForce GTX 660M. Nvidia’s requirements also list a Core i5 or equivalent CPU (AMD processors included). Quick Sync does not play a role in this relationship. Rather, the GPU renders the game locally on the PC. Its fixed-function NVEnc logic turns the output into an H.264-encoded video, which is then sent to the Shield over a suitably-fast wireless network. The company says an 802.11a/g/n router should be enough. That makes sense—you shouldn’t ever need 54 Mb/s of throughput for a compressed video stream. But peak performance isn’t the issue. I’m more interested in how high of a data rate the network needs to sustain, at minimum, to achieve smooth playback. Dips in the wireless valley matter most. The Shield does its part with a dual-band 802.11n radio from Broadcom, two transmit antennas, and two receive antennas. If you’re able to match the handset up to a MIMO-equipped router, dual spacial streams should give you higher throughput at any given distance, improving the likelihood you’ll have a fluid experience. At launch, Nvidia says it will support streaming PC games from your PC to the Shield. You will be able to connect an HDMI cable to your TV and mirror the output there. In the future, the company hopes to stream directly from your PC to the TV, using Shield as a controller. What won’t happen, it sounds like, is a wireless link between the PC and Shield, and a wireless link between the Shield and TV, which would introduce too much latency.

Topic.Title: Integrated Baseband v.s. Discrete?

Message.Msg: I am sure you can find tons of information if you just google SDR LTE. I don't think there is much discrete opportunity for Nvidia other than Tegra 4 attached solution. I can't imagine A6, Exynos, QCOM etc. solution ever using an Icera solution regardless of how cheap and space efficient the solution is. Like most SDR solution, some host protocol will probably be required to run on ARM core on Tegra itself. Just looking at this objectively - Icera 410, 450 etc. have not found a slot in most Tegra 3 design. The only solution that I am aware of is Asus Vivotab that uses Icera 410. I would like to hear why Nexus 7 did not use Icera (I think they use Intel/Infineon).

Topic.Title: charlie_best_here

Message.Msg: Whaaaat??? More Nonsensical discussion of Jen's Tegra folly ramping? From getting-paid-for-posting-on-seekingalpha -- engineering student ashraf.eassa. Who now writes, "If you paid attention to past conference calls, like a best-of-the-best securities analyst, you would know that Tegra SoCs are actually higher margin than GPUs on average. This means that once Nvidia can ramp the Tegras to the right revenue level, it will be quite positive for the top AND bottom lines." Son, perhaps you haven't actually READ nvidia's 10Q's? You know, the Report Card on how much money Jen's Tegra/CPB folly is Losing. Here. I've updated it for the Estimated 2013 Tegra losses. Op. Losses ____ Revenues ____ Year Ending ($330,000,000) ___ who cares __ January 29, 2013 Estimate ($207,913,000) ___ $591,166 ___ January 29, 2012 ($153,351,000) ___ $197,613 ___ January 30, 2011 ($94,170,000) ____ $156,047 ___ January 31, 2010 ($52,367,000) ____ $136,334 ___ January 25, 2009 ($836,801,000) ___ Cummulative Tegra/CPB Operating Losses ($367,000,000) ___Plus: The amount of shareholder's cash pizzed-away buying Icera ($1,204,801,000) __ Approximate cummulative Losses on Jen's Tegra folly. Note that the Losses no doubt exceed One Point Two BILLION Dollars, since Nvidia only started to disclose their Tegra losses seperately in 2008. Prior to that they were just swept under the rug. Also note that the more tegra chips they sell, the more nvidia shareholders lose. And now ashraf.eassa posts about this and that potentially, someday, maybe, ramping? HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA! What a hopeless Dreamer that guy is. Seriously. As the nvidia 10Q's clearly show, the only thing Ramping, -- for five (5) straight years now -- are the Tegra Losses. ($1,204,801,000) That's equal to what -- $2 bucks per nvidia share. Gone forever.

Topic.Title: Nvidia gained GPU market share

Message.Msg: AMD's integrated graphic chipsets moved to the computing solution division over 21/2 years ago. Today their graphics division includes consumer discrete GPUs, Pro-graphic GPU's like Nvidia's Quadro maybe $25M, and their HPC cards like Nvidia's Tesla cards maybe $10M, and their console graphic revenue which is probably around $30Mand rising if rumors are true. In fact I would doubt if AMD's consumer discrete GPU sales is much more than $250M a quarter and approaching the point of no return for continued R&D investment. What was remarkable was their operating income in the graphics division went up from $18M to $22M. Rory did say he wasn't go to try and buy market share anymore. This has been good news because Nvidia doesn't have to try and compete on price like they use to a couple of years ago. Notice the GTX 680 is still selling for the same price as it was launched at 3 quarters ago. They can certainly depend on Intel to crush the price on low end X86 processors and reducing AMD's ability to fund R&D. It's going to be pretty hard for AMD to fund the next leap on GPUs to 20nm. So Nvidia will just continue to accumulate cash to fund who ever makes a run at them for a buyout. Not kidding. I don't think Nvidia has a clue about what to do to avoid this. LOL

Topic.Title: Nvidia gained GPU market share

Message.Msg: Correction - AMD might sell $2-3M in HPC cards. and one further thought. With Intel's $300M payment before the end of the month and around $200M in Q4 cash flow, Nvidia will have accumulated $6.30 a share in Cash even while paying out $45M in dividends. That's 52% of the share price in Cash. That is unheard of with a company growing revenue and earnings. Note: Intel has 3 more yearly payments of $200M each left to go and I don't think at the end of the agreement they will pull integrated graphics out of their X86 processors do you? I feel that the only thing that can prevent someone from making a run at the company is a REAL SERIOUS SCIENCE PROJECT WITH MUCHO SPENDING INVOLVED. Perhaps that is what Project Shield is meant to be? But alas...Nvidia just may have a winner on it's hand and the cash will just keep rolling in... Carl, Carl Icahn, where are you? Look at IBM - They have paid out 103% of free cash flow in dividends and stock buybacks and the stock price in 4 years and the stock price has risen 2.5 times.Now that's what I call shareholder friendly. LOL

Topic.Title: Nvidia gained GPU market share

Message.Msg: Some wishful thinking sure...but WS M/A is coming back on line. At $12 a share with $6:30 a share in cash after 4Q cash flow and Intel royalty. Plus another $1 a share from the 3 remaining years of the Intel royalty agreement, plus annual cash flow cash accretion of $1 to $1.50 a share...at what point does a buyer appear? Think of it this way..... Cash Jan 2013 - $6.30 a share Cash Jan 2014 - $7.50 a share Cash Jan 2015 - $8.75 a share Cash Jan 2016 - $10.25 a share Share price $12 to $13. At what point does a deal look attractive to you? I mean after all the Board of Directors is almost completely Private Equity investor firms. Check it out. The dividend which was shock to me...I never would have thought Nvidia would pay a dividend. Did You? Perhaps the Board suggested it....What might they be worried about? P.S. I never would have thought of Dell going private but it looks like it is going to happen. JMHO

Unless you see evidence that your thesis isn't playing out, you should be grateful that you can add at these low levels. If you're just trying to trade, then why bother talking about the company? Topic.Title: Nvidia gained GPU market share

Message.Msg: Long term story? I believe the company is worth around $15 to $16. I just see a quick way for management to get it to that price. If dumb ole me sees it that way...then certainly one or two WS wizards see the same thing. Maybe..... 1) Buyback shares starting with say 25 million and top out at 100 million in a year. 2) Juice the dividend Or.....suffer the consequences and have your company bought up. P.S. - True story...I once worked for a semiconductor company where the founder tried to fight off a hostile takeover. It was not a good experience. People didn't know how to act...the Board was divided and long standing relationships were thrown up in the air. When the stock popped I left for greener pastures with the cash from my vested stock options. P.P.S---Ashraf ---I hope you didn't drop out of college to write full time for S/A.

Message.Title: My my my. The 4Q results are Quite Ugly, boys.
Message.Msg: So many many 4Q reports today, boys. A multitudinous, myriad, mess of 4Q reports. And ALL quite Ugly. Ugly ugly ugly. Let's take a look at the multitudinous, myriad, mess of Ugly reports, shall we? Texas Instruments. ► 4Q profit Plummeted (-11%) ► TI wisely shifts away from the profitless mobile smartphone and tablet market. ► Operating Profit from embedded processor business Skyrockets +33% ► Too bad Jen didn't go into that. ► Outlook: The weak demand environment to continue. Advanced Micro Devices. ► Loss widens due to soft demand. ► 4Q profit Plummeted (-27%) ► Lost ($296 million) more than last year -- but probably less than Jen's Tegra did. ► Revenue Plummets (-32%) ► Rory Read acknowledged the Uncertainty surrounding PC demand. ► Outlook for revenue: MINUS (-9%), +/- 3% ► Took reserve for planned 1Q work force reduction. ► Asks if anybody knows where the heck their 100,000 secret documents went. IBM. ► Three (3) straight quarters of Declining revenues. ► 4Q Revenue falls (-0.6%) ► But earnings are Up +6.3%, due to astute management decision to sell Software. ► Rather than trying to sell beige goods, which are oh so out of fashion. ► To bad Jen didn't buy a software company -- rather than Icera. ► TurboTax® would have been a nice alternative acquisition. Timely. ► Write it once. Sell it for $49.99 to 200 million taxpayers. Whistle to Bank. ► Nice. Google. ► 4Q profit Up +6.7% ► Due to more folks clicking on Google's $5 buck ad words. ► Their mobile device folly was a disaster. ► Yes boys, a Disaster. ► Google's Motorola sink-hole Lost ($353 million) -- just in the 4Q alone. ► Motorola invited 1,183 associates to, well, dis-associate last year. Or be axed. ► No secret documents were stolen and given to nvidia. So far. ► Too bad Jen didn't go into selling $5 search words -- rather than buying Icera. Looks like yet another sleepless night for the nvda bagholders, right boys?

Message.Title: I Just Read AMD's Transcript And I Really Don't Know What Rory Is Talking About
Message.Msg: The only clear statement was..."We are Not discussing that" embeded solutions being 20% of the business by Q4 2013 and tablets being 50% in 3 years and something about SeaMicro being the rest. I heard that...wow..that's a transformation if there ever was one. Doubt they will ever go to 20nm for that. TI and Microchip run their embeded processors at 32nm to.130nm. From the financials I did get this. Cash decreased 273M to $1.2B. Yes debt exceeds that, but they are comfortable with $1.1B in cash and their minimum is $700M. What happens then....they go to debtor in possession financing? Other than normal cashless cash flow in q1 they have $175M payment to Global foundries for wafers they aren't taking and $31M in severance costs for employees, but they will stay above $1.1B in cash...Non-Math majors I guess. Oh and revenue is dropping 9% but they are certain that gross margin and operating income will be just as good as Q4. "Next Question please" Looks like the race is on for cash preservation. Shucks I was hoping for dividend and a stock buyback. P.S. read the transcript...They sound like Texas Oilmen talking up their next wildcat well. Oh and they did say that they lost more share in graphics...but they are bundling popular games with their graphic cards so Q4 was the bottom. LOL
